p: A recent major issue during the last two decades concerning dairy sheep farming in the Mediterranean is the high ambient temperatures during the summer season and the first period in autumn. High ambient temperatures, combined with high direct and indirect solar radiation, low wind speed and increased relative humidity, are commonly faced by intensively reared animals that have to survive out of their thermoneutral zone (5 °C to 25 °C) [ 22] and maintain lactation, while possibly suffering from heat stress [ 23, 24]. Heat stress is a major limiting factor of dairy production in hot climates [ 25] that is often associated with oxidative stress, defined as the presence of a large amount of reactive oxygen species, exceeding the available antioxidant capacity of animal cells [ 26]. Plant extracts, rich in polyphenols, may support sheep that suffer from lipoperoxidation [ 27].
